author: Music Oldies
comment: OMG Watching this video brings back memories from when I was in that Amway bullshit. I remember getting bombarded with all that motivational crap about how I would make millions of dollars just by finding the "6 right people" to sponsor, who will then find 6, and then each of those 6 will find 6 and so on and on and on. After 10 years (where the hell was my good sense? LOL) I finally had enough with all of that nonsense and left and guess what? All of those bigwigs who promised that I would be their "friend for life" just disappeared out of sight and never returned any of my calls or emails. So much for being "one big family" and spending all that money on books, tapes & seminars just to make about a hundred dollars total which came to what, $10.00 per year BEFORE the motivational expenses? ü§£ü§£ü§£ü§£

author: robotpanda77
comment: The real common denominator in a con artist or scammer is the dumbass on the other end. If you can seriously look at some college kid telling you you can make 1000 a month doing nothing and not immediately think that sounds sus then you need to call up your momma and tell her what a bad job she did raising you. lol Something like bernie madoff makes more sense, this was a well respected man that had accomplished a lot legitimately and had made many people a lot of money. So when he came along with scheme number 3 it made sense to trust him. That is a far cry from some huckster telling you that chewing on this ball every day will make your jaw more defined or that wearing these blue eyeglasses will block out all that evil blue light from your pc that stops you from sleeping well. The first step here is to have accountability for yourself and admit that you let greed get the better of you. You knew it didnt sound right, you knew it didnt feel right. But you kept going. No more lottery tickets. Put in the work.

author: David Mah
comment: I started work as an intern with one of the current "Big 3" firms of Public Accountants.  I was fortunate that one of the audits assignment that I did was a pharmaceutical manufacturing company.  I learned and understand the supply chain and costing in producing various items including essential vitamins.  One day, a friend insisted that I accepted his invitation to attend a conference organized by a multinational MLM.  One of their products sold was various essential vitamins.  That MLM touted that their products and pricing are to help people to have healthier and better quality life.  I did a quick mental calculation and noted that their essential vitamins were sold at almost 10x to 15x the price to produce those.  I have stayed away from any MLM since.

author: Xavier Aou
comment:
English is my 3rd language, so please bare with me. I've always dreamed of breaking poverty especially that my great grandfather is my role model. He  had worked his life off and got wealthy from years of farming and trading goods. He started with nothing and he found a good partner and they both succeeded and they built wealth. My father alone got 7.3 million dollars and so his siblings, but they didn't know how to handle the money that they inherreted and in less than 10 years, they lost almost everything and some of them are still in debts. I remeber how spoiled I was and how many trips and toys and fun I had when I was a little kid. Never liked it tho. My father wouldn't let me clean my room or move my chair or clean my dish ... my mother was really upset with the lack of responsibility he had and he tried to teach us too. From a young age I knew my father would end up btoke and I was right. Now I'm 27 years old with a masters degree, me and my brother, we help our parents fanincially. I got fired from my first job 3 months AGO and living off my savings now and don't really know what to do, all I know is that I'm hating to go back to the 9 to 5 jobs .. and hating the greed that people have including my previous boss. I don't blame him because this is the world we live in today. Sometimes I feel really stupid and sorry for my naive self that I still think that  people can get rich quick and without being known and share their identities, faces, lives to gain customers and audience (which I hate), without putting masks and fake smiles, without sacrificing family time, without the greed, without selfishness .. I might be wrong !

My only regret now is not learning skills, even my father kept pushing me away from any hard work and mother advising me to focus on my studies (never will get rich and reach mu goals listening to both of them) so I didn't learn any skill and I didn't try any hatd work, just kept studying and waiting for the right time (after I finish my studies that I have no passion about) to start those methodes of getring tich quick because all I want is to have money and travel and have fun again and most importantly, give that luxioury back to my poor family. 

To sum up, I really want to be rich to travel and secure my future (as a single and a child free guy by choice) and help others, but I'm scared to become a monster in the proccess ! 

I see people in hoolywood do anything for money and fame, they are hungry for power, leading and controlling others. I see billionaires with youtube channels and still working in their 90s .. I see billionaires with low stabdards .. This  really scares me, I don't want to be like that. So maybe I will never get rich in this day and age. Family always compaires me with my grandfather, so if I were born in his time, I would get rich like him too. Now, I am loosing interrest day after day because our world has become too ridiculous, greedy and superficial

author: Ear Plug TV
comment: Really enjoy the way you approach your chosen topic. You express yourself in a sobering manner that replicates the internal dialogue of someone approaching a precarious decision. I run a small business started by my dad (Proud Nepo Baby) While life isn‚Äôt always sunshine and rainbows we are able to provide for ourselves and most importantly offer a wonderful product and service to our customers. Even though I may never make anywhere close to what these individuals make in a thousand lifetimes, there is a level of self respect in knowing I make my customers lives better with the product we sell. For anyone reading this seeking to strike it rich, I‚Äôd wager to try and find something you enjoy and build something around that. Even if it fails you‚Äôre going to enjoy the process and the people you meet. But on the other hand if it does reach a level where it can sustain yourself and the ones you love you can consider yourself extremely successful. I understand what I say is obvious and trodden, but so many things in life try to belittle the life that you have while dangling something better in front of you. However if you look around and see the beauty in your life and the blessings you have, life is pretty damn good for the short time we have to live it.

author: xtofer
comment: Don Lapre killed himself in 2011. According to a June 15, 2011, Associated Press article, Lapre was indicted by a federal grand jury in Phoenix, Arizona, on June 8, 2011, on accusations of running a nationwide scheme to sell worthless Internet businesses. Federal prosecutors accused Lapre of bilking more than 220,000 victims out of nearly $52 million. He was charged with 41 counts of conspiracy, mail fraud, wire fraud, promotional money laundering, and transactional money laundering. A federal judge issued a bench warrant for Lapre on June 22, 2011, after he failed to appear at his arraignment.

author: Denise Boertje
comment:
All the gurus selling whatever they‚Äôre selling to the public, it is not, I repeat NOT how to get honest wealth. They are only selling BOOKS, TAPES, VIDEOS, CLASSES. One is NEVER enough. One tape, one book, one class. 

I got roped into attending a ‚Äòseminar‚Äô on getting rich by flipping real estate with no money of my own! Never mind I had under $400 in my account, my credit was in shambles from my recent divorce. The hard sell was incredibly uncomfortable and high high pressure! I finally told the two jerks who were pressuring me I would sign up if there was a money-back guarantee. End of session. Every time they contacted me, id repeat the money-back guarantee request. They finally let me be. 

Wanna get rich super quick? Sell illegal drugs. Serious wealth is built with smart, hard work, despite ups and downs in the market, or inherited. Or by doing something criminal. Oh yeah! I forgot bank robbery, extortion, and blackmail for immediate wealth. Silly me. 

I had a client who, with his partner and their wives, was the largest holder of a popular fast food franchise west of the Mississippi. He‚Äôd opened every restaurant himself with his partner. It took them 9 years before they saw $1 million in profit. But every restaurant was profitable, but they took the profit to continue to live modestly and invest in new restaurant openings. When I met them (28 years after they started), they‚Äôd become multimillionaires, lived in serious mansions, drove Rolls Royces, BUT they‚Äôd also drop everything to go help out one of their stores. I saw them both go in their custom tailored suits to a store that had a mass shortage of bodies (due to everyone getting food poisoning) and pull a 10 hr shift from lunch through dinner plus side prep. I saw them open a franchise in the most crime ridden neighborhood and work there for months, and saw the party they threw for those employees when they hit a million in sales 3 months after opening which was 18 months before target date. Bottom line, hands on, willingness to do any menial task to make the business work, super support for their stores, and profit-sharing with ownership buy-ins. 

All these gurus are full of ca. End of story! üòÇ

author: SithLordmatthew
comment:
I know this topic all too well. In my 20s it was get rich quick in real estate. You would start with infomercials. Then a free seminar at the local airports hotel. Then you were group pressured into buying the course. Then came the 4 day real estate retreat for around $2000. 

Probably wasted 3-4 thousand all told on crap like that. But it was money well spent. Your buying your scam education. And when you graduate from that you don't have to pay that tax again. So every one of those since about 92 had no chance to get their hooks in me. In fact I have saved many people by recognizing what they were getting into and stopping them. It helped with avoiding pyramidal marking scams like drinks and insurance. When your eyes are open you see right through it. Iv never lost a cent with crypto or any other of the digital crap. No Ponzy schemes. Experience is best teacher.

author: Richard Cutler

author: Phil
comment: The law of attraction is a very real law. But its misinterpreted and misunderstood especially by the grifters who use it to manipulate people into feeling like they need to buy into their program. The law of attractions real purpose is to improve our soul condition by bringing us events that expose our lack of love. The irony is there is a lot of truth that people live in poverty due to their own actions, and law of attraction. But the law is trying to expose issues that they have in many areas... usually in areas like self-responsibility, fear of lack of money, fear of insecurity etc etc. This is also what the MLM guys prey on. And even being drawn to an MLM scheme is one of your own laws of attraction - to help you learn about these fears and issues you have. Its great that you make these videos Jani as a way to share what you've learned. Thats a great demonstration of how we've understood the lesson and helping others learn it too, as many fail at the same lesson time and time again

comment: It's not just gurus, there are legit companies too that do this.  For example, the financial company formerly called "Freedom 55" used to play on the dreams of people of retiring at the age of 55, which is 10 years earlier than the normal retirement age. author: Victor Fernando Guevarra
comment: You're exactly me about 15 or more years ago. I thought i was just a negative thinker when all these get rich quick scheme entered my stratosphere. I have a natural inclination to doubt something too good to be true even at my earliest years approaching adulthood. That was 1996 when me and my college close friends encountered MLM that promised us salvation for all our worldly problems. The thing is, I hated myself back then for not being sold like all of my friends did. I told myself that it's maybe because I don't have any ambitions in life. Ultimately though, I plunged in (mainly to fit in the group). I was introduced to law of attraction  and motivational stuff which most are good to be fair and i was kinda moved. I lost a lot of my savings and I was in debt on the process but i did not stop there, I continue to do so in a number of these get rich quick scheme which are, I think its safe to say on its golden age in those period. I continue to fail and fail miserably I did. I finally called it quits. I just went back to what I do good and make a living out of it. Looking back, I could still say that my experience with those gave me a wiser recognition in detecting BS in almost all things that I also applied in my present work. I love everything you do. This is exactly what I wanted to do or expose way back many years but doesn't have the talent or the guts to do so. I am so thankful that somebody else did it for me. More power to you brother!

author: Lucie Ciepka
comment:
90% of my YouTube history was TedTalk, one day I stumbled on a Tai Lopez talk, it was interesting it shared something valuable and I still remember it. YouTube decides that ‚Äúyou watched this-> you should watch this too‚Äù Tai Lopez‚Äôs video on how to read a book per day‚Ä¶ then his videos quickly became ‚Äúlook at my cars‚Äù after the third video I felt like I‚Äôm not learning anything new so I stopped watching, but by that time  YouTube had decided I may also like all kinds of gourous. Fortunately I have a good financial education from childhood and I studied communications in university, so I know what marketing technics they are using and how the speech is elaborated to make you feel like they are telling you some, it‚Äôs just that you don‚Äôt get it. 
I recommend to anyone to shuffle a bit their YouTube as often as you can: you go to a randomiser on the net you get the first two unrelated words, and a random number, search them in YouTube take the random number video ‚ñ∂Ô∏è and go do something else as long as YT thinks you are watching, put a like. Do the same thing next week. It will prevent the rabbit hole.

author: adam freeman
comment: once again a good insertion of Bernie Madoff in there. I remember the case back in 2007/08 I think - major league ponzi  scheme conman. i remember this Herbalife seminar I went to at some hotel in Hammersmith London, back in 1999. Like you say you tend to find these creatures (or they find you) when you are at your lowest and most desperate for cash. I didn't know much about MLM at the time, but that is what they were pushing. Using fake charm, and sloppy white marker board presentation delivery and rapid fire verbal delivery of financial bullshit. Came across to me as very unprofessional - but then I come from a formal teaching background. But the worst thing was they had human plants around the room who would approach you suddenly and act pseudo friendly (with that cult smile on the face) and try to extract personal info out of you with a view to on the spot recruitment. Being naturally suspicious and not desperate to become part of any group in any case, I gave false info and slipped out of there. All I can say is that these people are predators. That's it.

author: DDynamite is awesome
comment:
James I really agree with your narrative, I've gone down the same path before.

My maine gripe with this video is that the main example u gave (Vemma) does not align with your main point (about Gurus that make their money from teaching and not doing what they teach). 

Yes, both can be get-rich-quick schemes that we should avoid, but MLMs and pyramid schemes are a completely different problem. 
MLMs have unfair incentive structures that heavily benefit the founders and early members, while the new members have to essentially establish the same hierachy below them, that the people above have just to enjoy the rewards that the people above enjoy ( which in turn benefits those at the top).

Course Gurus either sell courses because they cant get the results they want from doing what they teach, or cannot scale their own business past a certain point (i.e. service based agencies)

Its not perverse incentives if its the latter, where the gurus have seen success and results before, although at a small-medium scale. Case in point, a lot of service based businesses (whether they sell courses or not) struggle to scale past 8 figures bc its a people based industry and its difficult to scale the founder's formula past the first few teams that the founder can directly teach.

The next question then is should we be paying thousands of dollars for these courses that are taught by successful business owners? Some might argue so, since its very possible that these business owners have that secret sauce that is marginally superior to everyone else in the industry, giving them the upperhand, thus qualifying them to be Gurus and justifying their pricey courses. 

My advice is this, especially for those WHO ARE STARTING OUT: That extra 
"special" knowledge that Gurus charge for is unnecessary if you're just starting out, and you would be better served by similar courses on platforms like Udemy. Seriously, whatever Guru's course u are considering, theres probably a similar one on Udemy for a hundred quid, taught by a similarly qualified instructor with relevant experience. If somehow that Guru's course has some special sauce that would give u a marginal edge over the competition, I'm sure you will figure it out with experience and trial and error in that business/ industry. My point is that u can get your business started with a 10-100 times lower  (learning) cost.

Also, when u setup a new account on Udemy, u can get most courses FOR A FLAT FIXED OF UNDER $20 BUCKS. Just decide the course slowly and start a new account when you are ready to purchase. 

Thats all u need to start any business from whichever Guru's course for $20 :)

author: Pat Man
comment: i goofed off in college so i didn't have anyone knocking on my door when I graduated.  I had to work retail right out of college.  I eventually went into telecom sales, then ran a few businesses, which didn't do very well.  The first 15 years of my career can be summarized as long hours and low pay.  I eventually got hired by a Fortune 500 company and quickly rose thru the ranks.  I have done very well the last 12 years and have earned enough for a nice retirement.  What i have learned from my experiences is the money and title of my position is not the reward.  When I look back I realize how much I learned grinding it out, and how it helped me improve my character which is priceless.  During those first 15 years of my career I learned patience, work ethic, made great relationships with customers and coworkers and many other things.   If you were lucky enough to strike it rich quickly you miss out on great character development.  Think of famous actors, musicians, people who inherit their wealth, and all the trouble that follows.  My advice for someone who is young, work hard and enjoy the journey.

author: doug randall
comment: There were a number of people selling the idea that you could pay someone else's taxes and earn a huge return when the Town, City, County, or State did a tax sale of the property.  A guy around my area fell for it and used every cent he had on this scheme.  Well it turns out the Towns are not required to take the property and sell it.  He couldn't convince one town to seize the houses of little old ladies who were broke.  And some of the property that he bought were tiny strips of land (like a ten foot strip along a right of way that ran a hundred yards) that only the abutters might be interested in for a couple of hundred dollars.  He lost everything and then went to the Town Hall and killed people before he killed himself.  He didn't even realize that it was the TV huckster that had tricked him.  Never realized that if the Huckster was onto a system that paid huge profits he wouldn't be selling a book on late night TV, he would be piling up the cash as quietly as possible.

author: BD Walters
comment:
The newest term for a MLM or Pyramid Program is "Direct Sales"....the same principles are at play. The owners enlist people and those people enlist others...my sister is at the 3rd level in her company and keeps referring to her "boss" who makes 100s of thousands a year sitting at home. Well, yeah, cause her underlings do all the work. She posts affirmations and motivations, has a stock pile of product, and does weekly teachings on how to succeed. 

I've told my sister my thoughts, but she's hooked. Now she has 4 people under her, but two of them are just not that into the super "Shebang" of the whole thing. They have kids and husbands who take precedence. 

Anyway...a few of the DS outfits have crumbled, and I'm sure some will succeed for awhile, but then a new disguise will surface and the cycle will "recycle" with a new crop of gullibles.

author: Dan Richter
comment: I spent my entire early 20s hypnotized by all the "get rich quick" content. I significantly delayed making any significant progress in life because my mindset was "if I'm not making homeruns, the game isn't worth playing." I put off going back to school because "best case scenario I'm making $80k per year... that's chump-change compared to my goals, so why bother?." I did manage to start a business, but it ultimately failed. However, I did transform myself in other ways by endlessly consuming books and this type of content for 5 years. I'm extremely disciplined, eat healthily, save large percentages of my income, exercise frequently, have very few bad habits/addictions, and finally only one semester away from becoming a registered nurse and have maintained a 4.0 GPA, significantly beating my 1.8 GPA in high school. Although I'm 27 and not a multi-millionaire per my goals at 21, I did manage to save and invest my way into a respectable net worth for my age and am happier with the course I'm on now.

author: JB
comment:
"No matter how educated, how smart, or how self aware you are‚Äî you can fall for this too."

No. No you cannot. Self aware, intelligent people do not even bother with too-good-to-be-true schemes. They are resourceful enough to not rely on things like acting or making money online. Instead, they use their own personal intelligence to do what needs to be done to establish themselves first, then when they've created a comfortable life, that's when they diversify their income potential. But they usually stick with traditional business practices and never waste their hard earned money on a monetary gambling scheme.

It's like cults.
When they say that anyone can be susceptible to get sucked into a cult...No, no, no. Rational and mentally sound people who are stable will never waste their time and energy by devoting it to something that isn't even realistic. Its just not possible to talk a stable and healthy person into shit like that. If you disagree, then you're obviously trying to think emotionally about it and using some example of a person you think you knew and how they got GOT. You didn't know that person, because they obviously weren't healthy and mentally stable when you weren't there. 

I dont know why sympathy is even brought up when describing the consequences of joining a scam or a cult. You should have known better. End of story.

author: Giorgos KOUSOULOS Kousoulos
comment:
One year ago, I was broke, jobless and I was living on by begging for coins outside churches. Today I am earning 2.000-3.000 dollars per month. In a few months I got a new car , brand new cloths, new appliances and here is how I did it. It is very easy.

Working 12-14 hours a day. That's it. Firstly I found a part time job to stay float. Then I found a full time job and worked by way to the top by working hard. I got promotions to both works. Then I learned how to create wooden flower pots by wooden pallets. I watched youtube videos, saved money to buy the needed equipment and started selling them. The wooden pallets are cheap to buy and they give you a good profit.

That's it. This is the easy way to make money. Learn a craft, get two jobs and work your a** off. It is easy because it is only 3 steps, but it is hard. Sometimes it will burns you out BUT when the end of the month comes and you get your 2.000-3.000 bucks you can get a weekend on a 4 star hotel to gain your strength back. 

There is no other way to gain easy money.

author: Green Deane
comment: I used to work in the guru industry. They are all fakes. My job was to write the stuff gurus say. Their presentations are memorized one-act plays. Everything is scripted, even the "spontaneous comments" when the tie is loosened, the language to persuade him and her, the offering, its timing... we tested everything before paid audiences and then in the field. It is legal pickpocketing, selling expensive goods or services to the weakest person in the room. Every presentation was crafted so that what the guru was telling you seemed like the most reasonable thing to do. A well-honed presentation sold a third of the room consistently.

author: Jeremy Wayne
comment:
I was in Vemma back in 2015 and actually met people like BK Boreyko, Alex Morton, Vincent Ortega Jr., Eric Worre, and others in Phoenix. I have videos about that on my channel. It was all very exciting at the time. I was gonna be somebody! I was gonna travel, buy houses, and prove my friends and family wrong! While I ultimately did not get rich, I did learn a few things about myself: I was insecure, gullible, and desperate.

I really like this video and your MLM video because they echo a lot of my own experiences throughout my journey in internet marketing. I bought into the whole idea of getting rich from network marketing first back in 2009/2010. It really is like a vortex of delusions that sucks you into a world of endless possibilities... and when I say endless, I also mean bad things, like debt, broken friendships, and low self-esteem. I am now an open advocate against network marketing, even though I still know many people who do them. I fell very hard in 2016 for something that ended up hurting my family. I tried to speak out against it and was threatened with lawsuits. The skills I had acquired gave me some leverage to at least get my money back (well, the cost to join at least).

Was my foray in MLMs and network marketing a complete waste? No, not at all. I learned digital marketing skills that helped me land my current corporate role. I am also in the process of starting my own SEO/SEM agency to consult for small to medium-sized businesses. I count my website building, blogging, and page ranking as viable experience, because it did produce results, even if I didn't become a millionaire from selling healthy energy drinks. I didn't like the person I was while I was trying to sell a dream lifestyle, but I definitely love where I am now.

author: IKnowBetterThanYou
comment:
Hey brother - when I was in mid-teens I was reading all sorts of real estate investment books. I also worked at multiple  inbound telemarketing companies, taking orders for different grq systems, diet packages, "collectable" coins, music collections... basically everything that had a infomercial or a commercial. The worst part was some companies would string on multiple upsells of sometimes completely unrelated products and services. One of the largest companies really had no qualms taking orders for absolutely anything with out any ethical or product quality concerns.

Around the same time, a classmate tried to recruit me into a nutritional supplement pyramid organization. I left my hourly job early, got dressed up in my best clothes and went to an office building where the organization had rented a small office, set up a cheap table and tablecloth, and had laid out bottles of "health supplements". Having been sucked into a pyramid scheme as an adolescent, it took only a few minutes into the presentation for me to realize what this was. As I got up to leave, my classmate pulled me to a chalk board and started drawing the pyramid network I could build. "You know <mutual acquaintance 1> and <mutual acquaintance 2>. And the both know at least 2 people, right?" oh boy.

author: Stephen Cholette
comment: This will sound terrible, but I love these fake gurus. They keep people out of legitimate money-making operations because of their experience in the pyramid schemes, leaving them thinking a 9-5 is the only way to make money.  All the while I get to exist in these legitimate money-making areas without competition (for the most part). You can develop passive income, but no single passive income will be enoungh to survive on, you'll need dozens but that's okay, you only have to do something once. Dividends, proper investments, government bonds, ect. will make you money, just not a lot from one single source. Stack them up over a few years and you can make your monthly goal of passive income.

As soon as you see someone flashing a car or cash then get the hell out of there people, I'm an online/virtual business process manager and I have seen all I've needed to see to know these people are fake, I have a degree in business and have worked for the experience to open my sole trading business and it makes it hard when my field is in helping others in going through the process and projects in small business, with these scammers wreaking genuine peoples hard work and proper ethics, I'm planning (after my psychotherapy studies) to build and open another business in childhood and adolescent behaviour therapy but will have to wait another 1 1/2 years to do so.

Being in business will never be an easy way to get rich, I personally wen't into business because I needed to be able to be with my kids and work on their schedule and also I've always been so beyond independent I'd rather work alone and contract people if need rather then working a 9 to 5 that isn't fitting my independence nor my time schedule.

I remember a research showing that the odds of a random person being a millionaire within an MLM community is 1 out of 2million. In contrast, the odds of a random person being a millionaire in the general population is 1 out of 20000.

comment: Hi James! You are amazing! I've seen this video 2 months ago and have to check it now because I notice something in the comment sections of most of the YouTube Channels I'm watching related to crypto or investing like your channel (I see one from this video) or Alux. There are always a couple of comment thread that talk about someone being good at Crypto or investing. saying their investment has been doubled after a few weeks or so. It looks like a normal conversation but when you clicked on the profile and view the person's other comments you will see that they are posting the same comments over and over to different videos. This is also true with most of the accounts that reply within the thread and most those accounts are all created within the same month. I know you did a video about those who pose as a certain channel by intentionally mispelling the names to scam people. This might be their new way of scamming people. I hope you read this. Thank you for helping and educating us!

author: Omar P
comment: I feel that Inbound Closer falls in the same category as the get rich quick schemes. Their spokesperson Peyton Welch makes ridiculous claims that you triple your earnings in 21 days and uses the trigger phrases/words.  All of his ads on Youtube follow the same formula. He complains about working at a retail store and puts a sob story and then says he used "the method". Boats, Lamborghinis in his ads typical. He never explains "the method" ever. He got lucky his brother is involved and carried him all the way. Its pretty much calling and closing deals and hope to make a commission and few actually succeed. The social proof he presents is fabricated and leaves a lot left to desire. The course it's self is way too overpriced for such basic information. $497 for the advanced course what a joke. Don't fall for these scams. The Inbound Closer people probably have bots accounts ready to attack accounts and channels who critique them. I'd laughed if they come and attack this account because I'm right. False or misleading marketing for sure. Thanks.

author: nikushim666
comment: Always love when they counter its a pyramid with "no, its a triangle". Sooooo a pyramid in two dimensions. Sad part is some of these scammers play it coy, not flexing cash but rather pretend to be a expert in a profession. The big one right now is "Stock trading", vast majority of them demonstrating "live" trades are either using a Paper sim (IE a simulation using 20+ min old market data, with basically buy/sells being done with monopoly money) or they are having their cult followers pump and dump for them. First thing you really gotta ask your self when you see people selling courses/mememberships etc. Is if they are so successful doing it, why do they need to sell a course, and why would you invite more competition into your market?  In the US there is a loophole with Pyramid schemes that allows them to skirt the law. And that is at least 40% of the revenue has to come from the product. The way they get around this is having suckers who buy into the scheme to buy the product from them, and thus you have Countless MLM's all over the place.

author: Roger Shively
comment: My awareness and mental defense for crap like this came from a legit, pyramid bar company. I sold life insurance to union members. The environment and model was exactly a pyramid scheme except they had legit contacts to only be able to market DIRECTLY to union members. You could however have this members "refer" family members and give them "exclusive" access to better benefits. Anyway, the lesson came from being in the hardest salesman industry. Since then, sense of urgency, exclusive access, recruit members, etc instantly created a red flag. Some of which i even apply to hackers online.

author: L R
comment:
I‚Äôm going to explain why this video and videos like this will keep you poor forever.

Think of a time when you had a really good business idea, you thought about it over and over, analysed  all the possibilities, discussed the plan with friends to get their feedbacks and kept researching until eventually you conclude that the idea is not as good as you thought. 

That‚Äôs called a self critical loop and it‚Äôs the enemy of progress. Now imagine a time when you or someone you knew had a business plan threw caution to the wind and focused on the quickest and most effective way to get a plan implemented... maybe it didn‚Äôt work, maybe they lost money but they also probably did learn a lot faster with hands on experience than they would have using their intuition. Extraverted thinkers are at the top of most companies and they always ask, what‚Äôs the quickest and most effective way to get things done and they ask out loud, they look to experts and take information from different sources to build there own framework. 
They don‚Äôt spend too long slicing things down  in there head they learn on the job, they don‚Äôt dwell on loses or wins and they just keep going.. videos like this push two false and harmful narratives, 1) everyone that uses effective marketing techniques is a scam artist & 2) you should never take risks and always be cautious. This is Very harmful because it‚Äôs usually the ignorant but ambitious and willing to learn  people who succeed in life while the analytical ones who already know the answer just die as failures. I learned the hard way, I tried to talk my friend out of buying a ‚Äúget rich quick course‚Äù he didn‚Äôt listen and now he makes fairly decent money using what the course taught him(he does domain real estate) Could he have found the information for free? Probably, but would he have pursued it at all if it wasn‚Äôt for those YouTube ads? Probably not.

comment: Sometimes especially when you are low, it is easy to fall for these con men. If you follow and watch closely in the way each one of them conducts, you see the pattern. Also I had seen quite a few guys go bust doing MLM business/Pyramid schemes and going bust in my circle, it also felt a little cultist and fortunately I never had enough money to invest in their courses or businesses so I was safe. Then I discovered there were videos exposing their game plan and I thanked myself for not falling into their trap. Moreover you should also do value proposition  as to why would someone try so hard to sell you a secret for a p√®edly amount. Bill Gates may do charity never sell a couse to become next Microsoft. Also if you watch their life style you see they lay roo much focus on themselves and lavish spending and a real businessman is anything but a reckless spender, he/she will only spend if there is better cost benefit analysis. So beware of these snake oil salesman. Nice video

author: Mr. AP
comment:
Here's how you get rich: 

1. Develop a marketable skill set that requires a level of time investment in training/education (gourmet chef, heart surgeon, trial lawyer, etc.)
2. Avoid debt whenever possible
3. Save 30 to 50 percent of each paycheck month after month without fail
4. Invest these savings into a reliable savings vehicle that at the very least maintains purchasing power over a long period of time (stocks, bonds, gold, etc)
5. Repeat steps 3 and 4 for several decades 
6. Hire a trustworthy and competent estate lawyer to create an iron-clad trust/will so that your life savings is put to good use after you die (charity, inheritance to descendants, etc.)
7. Die rich

author: Starblaiz
comment: Can't help but point out the parallels with these Get Rich Quick "gurus" and how Donald Trump conned his followers into thinking an election was "stolen" from them. It's the same cult-like brainwashing that gets them to ignore facts and outside sources of information ("Mainstream media is all fake news! Only listen to me!"). It's no coincidence that Trump is invested in MLM's like Herbalife, and even had his own MLM (Trump University) which was shut down right after he became president. On Jan 6th he told his followers during the insurrection "we love you" and "you are very special people" - classic love bombing like in any MLM cult. It's a critical flaw in human psychology that we need to find a fix for, because it's a dangerous vulnerability.

author: Makubaku
comment: If anyone of you thinks that 9-5 jobs are completely failures, a quick reminder that the teacher, police officer, firefighter, guard, ambulance driver, doctor etc etc are mostly 9-5 jobs (maybe they might have a lot of times when they work more) but these jobs are the essence that make our world progress, advance. The people who work 9-5 jobs are heroes, not the "entrepreneurs" that tell you to drop out school and open your business and become entrepreneurs. Money is just a piece of paper that can help you in life in some matters but in no way must be the focus of your life. Find your ideal and purpose in life even thought nothing matters at all but we as humans we are absurdists and we do things that have meanings for us. So before you waste your life chasing money, do something with purpose and enjoy your life because after all one day we will die and I know none of you wants to live a life where they chased a piece of paper to buy materialistic things which never truly made you happy. Don't let someone's opinion become your reality. Live your life as you want it and most importantly enjoy it. After all every human will work till they die, because work is what seperates us from the other creatures.

Hey Jani! 
I am also learning editing and acting and speech. I have a lot of knowledge in the building and renovating sector. So I started a Youtube channel, just like you did. Today I am making about 70‚Ç¨ per month, so slowly and steadily trying to turn my hobby and passion into full-time work. author: Army of Cats
comment: One thing that drives me crazy with the "dropship" get rich quick schemes specifically is that they've infiltrated platforms that are meant to be for legitimate small businesses. Etsy and eBay are overflowing with them. I usually shop on Etsy because I want to support an independent artist who makes everything themselves. And I try to use eBay as an alternative to Amazon because a lot of small mom & pop stores use eBay as a selling platform. Nowadays it's almost impossible to tell who is a small business or independent artist and who is just some random bro who set up a drop ship account, and if I purchase something from them I'll end up getting an item from Alibaba, Wal-Mart, or Amazon, the very places I was trying to avoid.

author: Lawrence Akainyah-Jectey
comment:
I remember how I fell for the Max International scheme during my second year at the university. 
A friend introduced me to it...but it wasn't until after my second month in it that I started noticing the trends. They never really marketed their products. I started spending more money than I had, even in that short period.
But what really took me out of it was the dubious ways in which they sold their supplements to people with serious health conditions who were desperate to find solutions. My background in biological sciences became a catalyst for my exodus. 

Thank you very much for this video James.
I strongly believe that a lot more people need to hear more stuff like this.

author: Days and Words
comment:
Another red flag for anyone who happens to read this is a really complex system of payment and reward. "You buy X for just $3, and then you sell it for $10, and $5 of those dollars you get to keep."
Target: "OK so I make $2 per sale?"
Them: "No, of course not! That would be a scam wouldn't it? No no, you make the whole $10 minus the $5 *under breath* and the $3 you spent on X.
Also you can buy 500 packets of X for just $500, so that way they're only $1. But in order for us to let you buy 500 at once, we need a $1000 refundable non-refundable payment."
Target: "OK when would I get my refund on that?"
Them: "Non-refundable if you ask for the refund or if you sell all 500 units. Also there is Gold tier which means units are free plus $2.95 postage even though you're picking them up yourself in minimum orders of 1500. You get to Gold tier by selling 803 units in your first two months, and if you sell 802 units there is a "success fee" of $1400 but you'll have made so much money it won't matter."
Target: "By my calculation I'll have made $1604."
Them: "So you can make a PROFIT of $204 AND get into Gold tier. You can't lose."

author: KingOfMadCows
comment:
These MLM's and get rich quick schemes have no shame. They don't just prey on students. They prey on anyone who is vulnerable, either financially or emotionally. 

If you just lost a family member and you're greiving, they will prey on you and tell you how they can help you make money to take care of funeral costs. 

If you're in addiction treatment and trying to get sober, they will prey on you and talk about how they have a wonderful supportive "community" that will help you get back on your feet financially.

If you're an immigrant trying to get a green card or apply for citizenship, they will prey on you and tell you how they can help you make money to pay for immigration lawyers or just outright lie and say their company can help you extend work visas or apply for green cards.

author: Javi Inkling
comment:
Every time I hear the phrase "passive income" I can tell from a mile away that it's a whole load of bullshit, whether it's real estate, dropoff shipping, sales, stocks, cryptocurrencies, etc, you'll need to do your own research and become an expert of what you're doing as well as starting with investments you can afford with money you're willing to potentially lose if things go wrong so you can earn it back. But if you really want to earn a lot of money doing all of that you'll need to get a job or start your own business so you'll get a stable income where you'll get the money to invest as well as using some of that active income to cover your living expenses.

But if you really want to make a change in your economic situation you'll need to cast away the consumer within you, which ironically for these fake gurus that promise you wealth is what they're targetting, why else would they dangle the luxurious life like candy? They know you want all of that, the cars, the phone, the clothes, the jet flights, the penthouse, you name it. They want you to think you'll be rich by being a mindless consumer who doesn't work nor put any effort and form their own experience, which will only cause you to live in debt and live a lifestyle you can't afford while you're under their spell (cue the instagram posts promoting the scam). Once you stop chasing luxury and realize that wealth is not something to show off by the products you use, is when you'll realize that those "rich" entrepreneurs that try to sell you their "fantastic" course are not only way less wealthy than they want you to think but also profiting off of your naivety to keep their fake lifestyle so they can keep fooling you, they're truly the nastiest type of parasite.

author: Micic Uros
comment: Really incredible topic. I personally am in the middle of the "get rich quick" scheme, there is an echo chamber, and many of the red flags you spoke about. But... The hook is there, I am invested, I used to beat myself up pretty bad before but now I feel good. The course I am selling is good value and worth the money respectively, there is the shame element in it but I am personally out of it. It is only new people that are getting in who get into the scheme and I also have the possibility to change the scheme for the people I sell to. I am very passionate about the topic, I am learning a lot, I am developing myself and putting myself out there, developing sales skills. I don't see this as a path to the rainbow but just a stepping stone to a new ground. Many of the people who are in it say that the course and service itself is worth the money even if people don't make a sale. So technically I don't have the guilt BUT... I also know that many people from my fellow colleagues will not have it good, they will feel robbed they will not be served the way they may have been promised but that's out of my hands. For the things inside of my hands, things are great except for the fact that I didn't made a sale yet... the whole thing is screaming irony but what you gonna do :/

author: Alvin Jackson
comment:
I have to say this because it needs to be said (knowing I love James' videos)...Getting rich "fast" is what everyone should expect in today's world, especially running an online business. The idea of "get-rich-quick" was a shady proposition when factory work and the industrial complex dependent on labor was a THING. This is no longer the case, thus, getting rich quick is feasible! James' own channel is proof of this!

Now don't get me wrong, the scumbags portrayed in this video are NOT who those who want more out of life should follow. I agree. However, the methods of making money fast are out there from reputable teachers and has personally worked for me. 

Amazon Book: Written and published in 30 days. 30 days later, I had my first $68.90 check and it grows every month. 
Online Course: $3,900 in 3 days from a promotion to my email list and grows every month. 
Affiliate For Course-Related products: $250-$1,500/month from email list and Youtube channel (I built the channel over the last 2 years). 

This was from one 6 month productive period, and I'll be paid for years to come. Is that fast enough? The mindset has to change about "get-rich-quick". It's antiquated and untrue for our time.

author: I Feel Half Naked
comment: This type of schemes is why less and less people are joining Olympic games, because they dont have the will power to do stuffs rather than thinking to get rich quick!

I have a story quite similar to yours. I had a dream that was simply not progressing and meanwhile I was broke. I wanted a better life for both me and my parents. So I dove head first into the "how to make money online world". I spent almost an entire year listening to bullshit from people like Dan Lok, Dan Pena, etc. Fortunately, like I already said, I was broke so I only spent like maybe $30 altogether on those online courses, but the effect it had on me, man... I was literally seeing all these numbers pop on my screen: $10k / month, $30k / month, $50k / month and it just had such a terrible effect on me. It literally made me feel so bad about myself for not achieving those numbers. Took me some time to realize it's all a pile of bullshit and all that money they make is either not even profit, or it's their salary from simply selling their course... Anyway, I really like the way you open people's eyes about this and I guess I just wish I had stumbled upon you earlier :/
